mainmatter.p: We begin with the schema of iteration and then proceed the more complex schema of primitive recursion and general recursion. Refer to TAPL.

tree.mainmatter: Giving two functions f, gf,gf, gf,g we can compose then to get a new function f \circ g = f(g(x))f∘g=f(g(x))f \circ g = f(g(x))f∘g=f(g(x)). Using \lambdaλ\lambdaλ-notation, we can define the composition of two functions as follows: f \circ g = \lambda x.f(g(x)) f∘g=λx.f(g(x)) f \circ g = \lambda x.f(g(x)) f∘g=λx.f(g(x)) And the composition operation is also a lambda abstraction. \circ = B = \lambda f. \lambda g. \lambda x.f(g(x)) ∘=B=λf.λg.λx.f(g(x)) \circ = B = \lambda f. \lambda g. \lambda x.f(g(x)) ∘=B=λf.λg.λx.f(g(x)) Composing identity function with any function does not change the function. We expect the following equation to hold: f \circ I = f = I \circ f f∘I=f=I∘f f \circ I = f = I \circ f f∘I=f=I∘f where IIII is the identity function. This can be verified by the following calculation: \begin {align*} B \space f \space I &= ( \lambda f. \lambda g. \lambda x.f(g(x))) \space f \space I \\ & \to _ \beta \lambda g. \lambda x.f(g(x)) \space I \\ & \to _ \beta \lambda x.f(I(x)) \\ & \to _ \beta \lambda x.f(x) \\ & =_ \eta f \end {align*} B f I=(λf.λg.λx.f(g(x))) f I→βλg.λx.f(g(x)) I→βλx.f(I(x))→βλx.f(x)=ηf \begin {align*} B \space f \space I &= ( \lambda f. \lambda g. \lambda x.f(g(x))) \space f \space I \\ & \to _ \beta \lambda g. \lambda x.f(g(x)) \space I \\ & \to _ \beta \lambda x.f(I(x)) \\ & \to _ \beta \lambda x.f(x) \\ & =_ \eta f \end {align*} B f I​=(λf.λg.λx.f(g(x))) f I→β​λg.λx.f(g(x)) I→β​λx.f(I(x))→β​λx.f(x)=η​f​ The last step requires an extensional equality, which is the called eta-conversion. \text {for} \space x \not \in \text {FV} (f) , \lambda x.f(x) =_ \eta f for x∉FV(f),λx.f(x)=ηf \text {for} \space x \not \in \text {FV} (f) , \lambda x.f(x) =_ \eta f for x∈FV(f),λx.f(x)=η​f It makes more sense to use the equation from right to left called eta-expansion (And more discipline has to be imposed or expansion does not terminate).

mainmatter.p: The well-known divergent combinator implies that the lambda calculus is not strongly normalizing.

However, we can always compute a normal form if one exists. Though there are many reduction strategies, there is a complete one for expressions that have normal form. This kind of reduction strategy is called normal order reduction or leftmost-outermost reduction. It scans through the expression from left to right and when it find a redex, it reduces it by applying beta reduction and returns to the beginning.
The notation of leftmost-outermost reduction is closely related to the notion of call-by-name evaluation in programming languages. (A little more distance to call-by-need evaluation in Haskell)
In contrast, call-by-value evaluation is not complete, which would reduce the argument of a function before applying beta reduction.

tree.mainmatter: The outcome of a computation eeee is its normal form. It is naturally to ask the question whether the normal form is unique. The key to this question is the Church-Rosser property or confluence: If e \to ^* e_1e→∗e1e \to ^* e_1e→∗e1​ and e \to ^* e_2e→∗e2e \to ^* e_2e→∗e2​, then there exists a term e_3e3e_3e3​ such that e_1 \to ^* e_3 \space \text {and} \space e_2 \to ^* e_3 e1→∗e3 and e2→∗e3 e_1 \to ^* e_3 \space \text {and} \space e_2 \to ^* e_3 e1​→∗e3​ and e2​→∗e3​ This implies the uniqueness of the normal form.

mainmatter.p: We can represent natural numbers in lambda calculus by using the Church numerals or Church encoding. The two abstractions should be related in some ways: one xxxx stands for zero and the other ffff stands for the successor function.

The Church numeral nnnn is a function that takes two arguments ffff and xxxx and applies ffff to xxxx nnnn times. The Church numeral 0000 is defined as the identity function \lambda f. \lambda x.xλf.λx.x\lambda f. \lambda x.xλf.λx.x. The Church numeral 1111 is defined as the successor of 0000: 1 = \lambda f. \lambda x.f(x) 1=λf.λx.f(x) 1 = \lambda f. \lambda x.f(x) 1=λf.λx.f(x) The Church numeral 2222 is defined as the successor of 1111: 2 = \lambda f. \lambda x.f(f(x)) 2=λf.λx.f(f(x)) 2 = \lambda f. \lambda x.f(f(x)) 2=λf.λx.f(f(x)) And so on.

The Church numeral nnnn is defined as the successor of n-1n−1n-1n−1: n = \lambda f. \lambda x.f^n(x) n=λf.λx.fn(x) n = \lambda f. \lambda x.f^n(x) n=λf.λx.fn(x) where f^n(x)fn(x)f^n(x)fn(x) means applying ffff to xxxx nnnn times.

The successor function is defined as follows: S = \lambda n. \lambda f. \lambda x.f(n \space f \space x) S=λn.λf.λx.f(n f x) S = \lambda n. \lambda f. \lambda x.f(n \space f \space x) S=λn.λf.λx.f(n f x)

mainmatter.tex: \begin {align*} S \space n &= ( \lambda n. \lambda f. \lambda x.f(n \space f \space x)) \space n \\ & \to _ \beta \lambda f. \lambda x.f(n \space f \space x) \\ & \to _ \beta \lambda f. \lambda x.f^n(x) \\ & \to _ \beta n+1 \end {align*} S n=(λn.λf.λx.f(n f x)) n→βλf.λx.f(n f x)→βλf.λx.fn(x)→βn+1 \begin {align*} S \space n &= ( \lambda n. \lambda f. \lambda x.f(n \space f \space x)) \space n \\ & \to _ \beta \lambda f. \lambda x.f(n \space f \space x) \\ & \to _ \beta \lambda f. \lambda x.f^n(x) \\ & \to _ \beta n+1 \end {align*} S n​=(λn.λf.λx.f(n f x)) n→β​λf.λx.f(n f x)→β​λf.λx.fn(x)→β​n+1​

mainmatter.p: Using the iteration property we can define mathematical functions over the natural numbers in lambda calculus. The addition of two Church numerals mmmm and nnnn is defined as follows: m+n = \lambda n. \lambda k. n \space S \space k m+n=λn.λk.n S k m+n = \lambda n. \lambda k. n \space S \space k m+n=λn.λk.n S k

The multiplication of two Church numerals mmmm and nnnn is defined by iterating the addition function mmmm times: m*n = \lambda n. \lambda k. n \space (k + ) \space 0 m∗n=λn.λk.n (k+) 0 m*n = \lambda n. \lambda k. n \space (k + ) \space 0 m∗n=λn.λk.n (k+) 0

The exponentiation of two Church numerals mmmm and nnnn is defined as follows: m^n = \lambda m. \lambda n. n \space (m *) \space 1 mn=λm.λn.n (m∗) 1 m^n = \lambda m. \lambda n. n \space (m *) \space 1 mn=λm.λn.n (m∗) 1

As we saw before, a natural number nnnn is represented by a function that iterates its first argument nnnn times on its second argument. n = \lambda g. \lambda c.g^n(c) n=λg.λc.gn(c) n = \lambda g. \lambda c.g^n(c) n=λg.λc.gn(c) Another way to specify such a function schematically is \begin {align*} f \space0 &= c \\ f (n+1) &= g \space (f \space n) \end {align*} f 0=cf(n+1)=g (f n) \begin {align*} f \space0 &= c \\ f (n+1) &= g \space (f \space n) \end {align*} f 0f(n+1)​=c=g (f n)​ If such a function satisfies such a schema of iteration, then it can be defined in the lambda calculus on Church numerals as f = \lambda n.n \space g \space c f=λn.n g c f = \lambda n.n \space g \space c f=λn.n g c This definition is total which means it is defined for all natural numbers. Let's define the multiplication again \begin {align*} m*0 &= 0 \\ m*(n+1) &= m + (m*n) \end {align*} m∗0=0m∗(n+1)=m+(m∗n) \begin {align*} m*0 &= 0 \\ m*(n+1) &= m + (m*n) \end {align*} m∗0m∗(n+1)​=0=m+(m∗n)​ To fit our schema of iteration, we can define the multiplication by abstracting over kkkk: \begin {align*} \text {times} \space 0 &= \lambda k.0 \\ \text {times} \space (n+1) &= \lambda k.k + ( \text {times} \space n \space k) \end {align*} times 0=λk.0times (n+1)=λk.k+(times n k) \begin {align*} \text {times} \space 0 &= \lambda k.0 \\ \text {times} \space (n+1) &= \lambda k.k + ( \text {times} \space n \space k) \end {align*} times 0times (n+1)​=λk.0=λk.k+(times n k)​ where the cccc and gggg are \begin {align*} c &= \lambda k.0 \\ g &= \lambda r. \lambda k.k+(r \space k) \end {align*} c=λk.0g=λr.λk.k+(r k) \begin {align*} c &= \lambda k.0 \\ g &= \lambda r. \lambda k.k+(r \space k) \end {align*} cg​=λk.0=λr.λk.k+(r k)​ and we obtain \text {times} = \lambda n.n( \lambda rk. k + (r \space k))( \lambda k.0) times=λn.n(λrk.k+(r k))(λk.0) \text {times} = \lambda n.n( \lambda rk. k + (r \space k))( \lambda k.0) times=λn.n(λrk.k+(r k))(λk.0)

Everything appears simply until we think of a very simple function, the predecessor function \text {pred}pred\text {pred}pred defined by \begin {align*} \text {pred} \space 0 = 0 \\ \text {pred} \space (n+1) = n \end {align*} pred 0=0pred (n+1)=n \begin {align*} \text {pred} \space 0 = 0 \\ \text {pred} \space (n+1) = n \end {align*} pred 0=0pred (n+1)=n​ What we would need is the schema of primitive recursion \begin {align*} f \space 0 &= c \\ f \space (n+1) &= g \space n \space (f \space n) \end {align*} f 0=cf (n+1)=g n (f n) \begin {align*} f \space 0 &= c \\ f \space (n+1) &= g \space n \space (f \space n) \end {align*} f 0f (n+1)​=c=g n (f n)​ With which we can define the predecessor function by g = \lambda x. \lambda y.x g=λx.λy.x g = \lambda x. \lambda y.x g=λx.λy.x

frontmatter.title: Primitive Recursion in Lambda Calculus › Define predecessor function

tree.mainmatter: The key idea is to gain access to nnnn in the schema of primitive recursion by rebuilding it during the iteration. \text {pred}_2 \space n = \langle n, \text {pred} \space n \rangle pred2 n=⟨n,pred n⟩ \text {pred}_2 \space n = \langle n, \text {pred} \space n \rangle pred2​ n=⟨n,pred n⟩ The key step is to express the definition by a schema of iteration rather than primitive recursion. \text {pred}_2 \space 0 = \langle 0, 0 \rangle pred2 0=⟨0,0⟩ \text {pred}_2 \space 0 = \langle 0, 0 \rangle pred2​ 0=⟨0,0⟩ We need a helper function for the successor case \text {letPair} \space \langle e_1,e_2 \rangle \space k = k \space e_1 \space e_2 letPair ⟨e1,e2⟩ k=k e1 e2 \text {letPair} \space \langle e_1,e_2 \rangle \space k = k \space e_1 \space e_2 letPair ⟨e1​,e2​⟩ k=k e1​ e2​ This function passes the elements of the pair to a continuation kkkk. \text {pred}_2 (n+1) = \text {letPair} \space ( \text {pred}_2 \space n) \space ( \lambda xy. \langle x+1, x \rangle ) pred2(n+1)=letPair (pred2 n) (λxy.⟨x+1,x⟩) \text {pred}_2 (n+1) = \text {letPair} \space ( \text {pred}_2 \space n) \space ( \lambda xy. \langle x+1, x \rangle ) pred2​(n+1)=letPair (pred2​ n) (λxy.⟨x+1,x⟩)

frontmatter.title: Primitive Recursion in Lambda Calculus › Define Pairs

tree.mainmatter: Now we need to define pairs and \text {letPair}letPair\text {letPair}letPair. The idea is to simply abstract over the continuation itself. \begin {align*} \langle x,y \rangle &= \lambda k.k \space x \space y \\ \text {pair} &= \lambda x. \lambda y. \lambda k.k \space x \space y \\ \text {letPair} &= \lambda p.p \end {align*} ⟨x,y⟩=λk.k x ypair=λx.λy.λk.k x yletPair=λp.p \begin {align*} \langle x,y \rangle &= \lambda k.k \space x \space y \\ \text {pair} &= \lambda x. \lambda y. \lambda k.k \space x \space y \\ \text {letPair} &= \lambda p.p \end {align*} ⟨x,y⟩pairletPair​=λk.k x y=λx.λy.λk.k x y=λp.p​ The letPair is not really needed here.

frontmatter.title: Primitive Recursion in Lambda Calculus › Summary

tree.mainmatter: Summarizing the above and we obtain the full definition of the predecessor function. \begin {align*} \text {pred}_2 &= \lambda n.n \space ( \lambda p.p ( \lambda xy. \text {pair} \space (x+1) \space x)) \space \text {pair} ( \space 0 \space 0) \\ \text {pred} &= \lambda n. ( \text {pred}_2 \space n) \space ( \lambda xy.y) \end {align*} pred2=λn.n (λp.p(λxy.pair (x+1) x)) pair( 0 0)pred=λn.(pred2 n) (λxy.y) \begin {align*} \text {pred}_2 &= \lambda n.n \space ( \lambda p.p ( \lambda xy. \text {pair} \space (x+1) \space x)) \space \text {pair} ( \space 0 \space 0) \\ \text {pred} &= \lambda n. ( \text {pred}_2 \space n) \space ( \lambda xy.y) \end {align*} pred2​pred​=λn.n (λp.p(λxy.pair (x+1) x)) pair( 0 0)=λn.(pred2​ n) (λxy.y)​

frontmatter.title: Primitive Recursion in Lambda Calculus › General Primitive Recursion

tree.mainmatter: The general case of primitive recursion follows by a similar pattern. We begin by defining a function f_2f2f_2f2​: f_2 \space n = \langle n, f \space n \rangle f2 n=⟨n,f n⟩ f_2 \space n = \langle n, f \space n \rangle f2​ n=⟨n,f n⟩ We can define f_2f2f_2f2​ using the schema of iteration \begin {align*} f_2 \space 0 &= \langle 0, c \rangle \\ f_2 \space (n+1) &= \text {letPair} \space (f_2 \space n) \space ( \lambda xy. \langle x+1, g \space x \space y \rangle ) \\ f \space n &= \text {letPair} \space (f_2 \space n) \space ( \lambda xy.y) \end {align*} f2 0=⟨0,c⟩f2 (n+1)=letPair (f2 n) (λxy.⟨x+1,g x y⟩)f n=letPair (f2 n) (λxy.y) \begin {align*} f_2 \space 0 &= \langle 0, c \rangle \\ f_2 \space (n+1) &= \text {letPair} \space (f_2 \space n) \space ( \lambda xy. \langle x+1, g \space x \space y \rangle ) \\ f \space n &= \text {letPair} \space (f_2 \space n) \space ( \lambda xy.y) \end {align*} f2​ 0f2​ (n+1)f n​=⟨0,c⟩=letPair (f2​ n) (λxy.⟨x+1,g x y⟩)=letPair (f2​ n) (λxy.y)​

mainmatter.p: When computing over natural numbers we can restrict the functions that can be formed in schematic ways to obtain a language in which all functions terminate. Because if cccc and gggg are terminating then so is ffff formed from them by primitive recursion.
In this note we complete the development of recursion. Refer to TAPL

tree.mainmatter: General Recursion Let's first consider the greatest common divisor function \gcd (a,b)gcd⁡(a,b)\gcd (a,b)gcd(a,b) \begin {align*} \gcd \space a \space a &= a \\ \gcd \space a \space b &= \gcd \space (a-b) \space b \text { if } b > a \\ \gcd \space a \space b &= \gcd \space a \space (b-a) \text { if } a > b \end {align*} gcd⁡ a a=agcd⁡ a b=gcd⁡ (a−b) b if b>agcd⁡ a b=gcd⁡ a (b−a) if a>b \begin {align*} \gcd \space a \space a &= a \\ \gcd \space a \space b &= \gcd \space (a-b) \space b \text { if } b > a \\ \gcd \space a \space b &= \gcd \space a \space (b-a) \text { if } a > b \end {align*} gcd a agcd a bgcd a b​=a=gcd (a−b) b if b>a=gcd a (b−a) if a>b​ This recursion is terminating because the arguments are decreasing. We can deal with this case currently and let's be hold. We consider the most general schema of recursion. f = h \space f f=h f f = h \space f f=h f which means that in the right-hand side we can make arbitrary recursive calls to the function ffff. For \gcdgcd⁡\gcdgcd we have h = \lambda gab. \text {if } (a=b) \space a \space (( \text {if } \space (a>b) \space (g \space (a-b) \space b) \space (g \space a \space (b-a)) )) h=λgab.if (a=b) a ((if  (a>b) (g (a−b) b) (g a (b−a)))) h = \lambda gab. \text {if } (a=b) \space a \space (( \text {if } \space (a>b) \space (g \space (a-b) \space b) \space (g \space a \space (b-a)) )) h=λgab.if (a=b) a ((if  (a>b) (g (a−b) b) (g a (b−a)))) How can we define ffff explicitly when given hhhh so that f = h \space ff=h ff = h \space ff=h f, which called a fixed point pf hhhh. If we believe Church-Turing thesis, then any partial recursive function should be representable on Church numerals in lambda calculus. Hence we can find such ffff and the answer is called Y-combinator. We want that if f = Y \space hf=Y hf = Y \space hf=Y h and f=h \space ff=h ff=h \space ff=h f, so we get Y \space h = h \space (Y \space h)Y h=h (Y h)Y \space h = h \space (Y \space h)Y h=h (Y h). Y \space h = h \space (Y \space h) = h \space (h \space (Y \space h)) = h \space (h \space (h \space (Y \space h))) = \cdots Y h=h (Y h)=h (h (Y h))=h (h (h (Y h)))=⋯ Y \space h = h \space (Y \space h) = h \space (h \space (Y \space h)) = h \space (h \space (h \space (Y \space h))) = \cdots Y h=h (Y h)=h (h (Y h))=h (h (h (Y h)))=⋯ This iterates infinitely. The definition of YYYY is: Y = \lambda h.( \lambda x. h \space (x \space x)) \space ( \lambda x. h \space (x \space x)) Y=λh.(λx.h (x x)) (λx.h (x x)) Y = \lambda h.( \lambda x. h \space (x \space x)) \space ( \lambda x. h \space (x \space x)) Y=λh.(λx.h (x x)) (λx.h (x x)) The application x \space xx xx \space xx x will replicate Y \space hY hY \space hY h: \begin {align*} Y \space h &= ( \lambda x. h \space (x \space x)) \space ( \lambda x. h \space (x \space x)) \\ &= h \space (( \lambda x. h \space (x \space x)) \space ( \lambda x. h \space (x \space x))) \\ &= h \space (Y \space h) \end {align*} Y h=(λx.h (x x)) (λx.h (x x))=h ((λx.h (x x)) (λx.h (x x)))=h (Y h) \begin {align*} Y \space h &= ( \lambda x. h \space (x \space x)) \space ( \lambda x. h \space (x \space x)) \\ &= h \space (( \lambda x. h \space (x \space x)) \space ( \lambda x. h \space (x \space x))) \\ &= h \space (Y \space h) \end {align*} Y h​=(λx.h (x x)) (λx.h (x x))=h ((λx.h (x x)) (λx.h (x x)))=h (Y h)​ The partial recursive functions include functions that are undefined (have no normal form) on some arguments, hence we can't always find an answer. Consider f=ff=ff=ff=f as a recursion schema and h= \text {id}h=idh= \text {id}h=id. Y \space h = Y \space \text {id} = ( \lambda x. \text {id} \space (x \space x)) \space ( \lambda x. \text {id} \space (x \space x)) = ( \lambda x. x \space x) \space ( \lambda x. x \space x) = \Omega Y h=Y id=(λx.id (x x)) (λx.id (x x))=(λx.x x) (λx.x x)=Ω Y \space h = Y \space \text {id} = ( \lambda x. \text {id} \space (x \space x)) \space ( \lambda x. \text {id} \space (x \space x)) = ( \lambda x. x \space x) \space ( \lambda x. x \space x) = \Omega Y h=Y id=(λx.id (x x)) (λx.id (x x))=(λx.x x) (λx.x x)=Ω The function f= \Omegaf=Ωf= \Omegaf=Ω solves the equation f=ff=ff=ff=f by giving a divergent result.

Define Functions By Recursion Consider the factorial function: \text {fact} \space n = \text {if } (n=0) \space 1 \space (n \space \text {fact} \space (n-1)) fact n=if (n=0) 1 (n fact (n−1)) \text {fact} \space n = \text {if } (n=0) \space 1 \space (n \space \text {fact} \space (n-1)) fact n=if (n=0) 1 (n fact (n−1)) This requires a test \text {if0}if0\text {if0}if0 satisfies: \begin {align*} \text {if0}(0,c,d) &=c \\ \text {if0}(n+1,c,d) &=d \end {align*} if0(0,c,d)=cif0(n+1,c,d)=d \begin {align*} \text {if0}(0,c,d) &=c \\ \text {if0}(n+1,c,d) &=d \end {align*} if0(0,c,d)if0(n+1,c,d)​=c=d​ We can define \text {if0}if0\text {if0}if0 by (Recall that K= \lambda xy.xK=λxy.xK= \lambda xy.xK=λxy.x): \text {if0} = \lambda ncd. n \space (K \space d) \space c if0=λncd.n (K d) c \text {if0} = \lambda ncd. n \space (K \space d) \space c if0=λncd.n (K d) c The argument of Y combinator is defined: h_ \text {fact} = \lambda g. \lambda n. \text {if0} \space n \space 1 \space (n \space g \space (n-1)) hfact=λg.λn.if0 n 1 (n g (n−1)) h_ \text {fact} = \lambda g. \lambda n. \text {if0} \space n \space 1 \space (n \space g \space (n-1)) hfact​=λg.λn.if0 n 1 (n g (n−1)) and \text {fact} = Y \space h_ \text {fact} fact=Y hfact \text {fact} = Y \space h_ \text {fact} fact=Y hfact​

mainmatter.p: The scanner's task is to transform a stream of characters into a stream of words in the input language. Each word must be classified into a syntactic category. This note refers to Engineering a compiler
The first stage of a compiler is to perform lexical analysis by a scanner. The parser or syntax analyzer will fit the stream of words to a grammatical model of the input language.

Scanner construction has a strong foundation in formal language theory. Scanners are based on recognizers that simulate deterministic finite automata. We can specify the lexical structure using a set of regular expression.

Each time a scanner recognizes a word, it will return a token that contains the word (lexeme) and its syntactic category. The scanner uses microsyntax (the lexical structure of a language) to find and classify words. Keywords are identifiers but have special meanings.
A char-by-char algorithm to recognize words is trivial. Consider we want to recognize the word new. We can write down the following code.
We can also represent the code fragment using the simple transition diagram.
Transition diagrams can be viewed as formal mathematics objects called finite automata.

A finite automata (FA) is a five-tuple (S, \Sigma , \delta ,s_0,S_A)(S,Σ,δ,s0,SA)(S, \Sigma , \delta ,s_0,S_A)(S,Σ,δ,s0​,SA​) where SSSS is the finite set of states in the recognizer including s_eses_ese​, the error state. \SigmaΣ\SigmaΣ is the finite alphabet used by the recognizer. \SigmaΣ\SigmaΣ is the union of the edge labels in the transition diagram. \delta (s, c)δ(s,c)\delta (s, c)δ(s,c) is the recognizer's transition function, which maps each state s \in Ss∈Ss \in Ss∈S and character c \in \Sigmac∈Σc \in \Sigmac∈Σ into some next state. In state s_isis_isi​ with input character cccc the FA takes the transition s_i \xrightarrow {c} \delta (s_i, c)si→cδ(si,c)s_i \xrightarrow {c} \delta (s_i, c)si​c​δ(si​,c). s_0 \in Ss0∈Ss_0 \in Ss0​∈S is the initial state of the recognizer. S_ASAS_ASA​ is the set of accepting states, S_A \subseteq SSA⊆SS_A \subseteq SSA​⊆S. \deltaδ\deltaδ is only partially defined. For all other combinations of the state s_isis_isi​ and input char cccc we can define \delta (s_i,c)=s_eδ(si,c)=se\delta (s_i,c)=s_eδ(si​,c)=se​.
An FA accpets a string xxxx and iff starting in s_0s0s_0s0​, the sequence of chars in xxxx takes the FA to an accepting state when the entire string has been consumed.

If the string xxxx consists characters x_1, x_2, \ldots , x_nx1,x2,…,xnx_1, x_2, \ldots , x_nx1​,x2​,…,xn​ then the FA (S, \Sigma , \delta ,s_0,S_A)(S,Σ,δ,s0,SA)(S, \Sigma , \delta ,s_0,S_A)(S,Σ,δ,s0​,SA​) accpets xxxx iff there is a sequence \delta ( \delta ( \dots \delta ( \delta ( \delta (s_0,x_1),x_2),x_3) \dots , x_{n-1} ) ,x_n ) \in S_A δ(δ(…δ(δ(δ(s0,x1),x2),x3)…,xn−1),xn)∈SA \delta ( \delta ( \dots \delta ( \delta ( \delta (s_0,x_1),x_2),x_3) \dots , x_{n-1} ) ,x_n ) \in S_A δ(δ(…δ(δ(δ(s0​,x1​),x2​),x3​)…,xn−1​),xn​)∈SA​

The char-by-char model is very simple and now we consider about numbers. For simplicity, we consider only unsigned integers: An unsigned integer is either zero or series of one or more digits where the first one is non-zero.
And the code implementation can be:

Another example is to recognize identifiers which are sequences of letters and digits, starting with a letter. Many languages include other special characters for identifiers. The FA for unsigned integers and identifiers are different in syntactic categories.

The set of words accpeted by a finite automata FFFF forms a language L(F)L(F)L(F)L(F). The transition diagram of FFFF specifies the syntactic structure of L(F)L(F)L(F)L(F). But such representation is complex and non-intuitive. Most systems use a notation called regular expressions to specify the language. Any language described by an RE is considered a regular language. RE is equivalent to FA.
To work with REs in a rigorous way, we need a foraml definition.

frontmatter.title: Simply Typed Lambda Calculus and Representation Theorems

mainmatter.p: We have explored the power of lambda calculus. Church's original purpose of the pure calculus of functions was a new foundations of mathematics distinct from set theory. Unfortunately the original lambda calculus is inconsistent (Every proposition has a proof). Church returned to the ideas by Russell and Whitehead and developed the Church's Simple Theory of Types. SLTC is a typed interpretation of the lambda calculus with only one type constructor \to→\to→ that builds function types.

We follow the converntion that function type constructor \to→\to→ is right-associative. We write e: \taue:τe: \taue:τ if expression eeee has type \tauτ\tauτ. \lambda x.x: \tau \to \tau λx.x:τ→τ \lambda x.x: \tau \to \tau λx.x:τ→τ But the type is not unique. The booleans can be typed: \begin {align*} \text {true} &= \lambda x. \lambda y.x : \alpha \to ( \beta \to \alpha ) \\ \text {false} &= \lambda x. \lambda y.y : \alpha \to ( \beta \to \beta ) \end {align*} true=λx.λy.x:α→(β→α)false=λx.λy.y:α→(β→β) \begin {align*} \text {true} &= \lambda x. \lambda y.x : \alpha \to ( \beta \to \alpha ) \\ \text {false} &= \lambda x. \lambda y.y : \alpha \to ( \beta \to \beta ) \end {align*} truefalse​=λx.λy.x:α→(β→α)=λx.λy.y:α→(β→β)​

Wem can formalize judgments about expressions and types using inference rules. For instance: \frac { e_1: \tau _1 \quad e_2: \tau _2 }{ e_1 \space e_2: \tau _2 } e1:τ1e2:τ2e1 e2:τ2 \frac { e_1: \tau _1 \quad e_2: \tau _2 }{ e_1 \space e_2: \tau _2 } e1​ e2​:τ2​e1​:τ1​e2​:τ2​​ The application e_1 \space e_2e1 e2e_1 \space e_2e1​ e2​ has type \tau _2τ2\tau _2τ2​ if e_1e1e_1e1​ has type \tau _1 \to \tau _2τ1→τ2\tau _1 \to \tau _2τ1​→τ2​ and e_2e2e_2e2​ has type \tau _1τ1\tau _1τ1​.

We can record the types of variable in a typing context. \Gamma : \equiv x_1: \tau _1, \ldots ,x_n: \tau _n Γ:≡x1:τ1,…,xn:τn \Gamma : \equiv x_1: \tau _1, \ldots ,x_n: \tau _n Γ:≡x1​:τ1​,…,xn​:τn​ And we always assume that all variables declared in a context are distinct. This avoids any ambiguity when we try to determine the type of a variable. The typing judgment now becomes \Gamma \vdash e: \tau Γ⊢e:τ \Gamma \vdash e: \tau Γ⊢e:τ

Are there expressions that cannot be typed in the simple type system? Yes, for example, \Omega = \lambda x.x \space xΩ=λx.x x\Omega = \lambda x.x \space xΩ=λx.x x cannot be typed. But how do we prove that \OmegaΩ\OmegaΩ cannot be typed?

We can apply the typing rules and get a contradiction. \OmegaΩ\OmegaΩ is a lambda abstraction hence we can assume that it has type \tau \to \sigmaτ→σ\tau \to \sigmaτ→σ. Then xxxx has type \tauτ\tauτ and x \space xx xx \space xx x has type \sigmaσ\sigmaσ. By the application of x \space xx xx \space xx x we get that \tau = \tau \to \sigmaτ=τ→σ\tau = \tau \to \sigmaτ=τ→σ, which does not exist.

To recover from this in full generality we need recursive types. \tau =F \tau τ=Fτ \tau =F \tau τ=Fτ where F= \lambda \alpha . \alpha \to \sigmaF=λα.α→σF= \lambda \alpha . \alpha \to \sigmaF=λα.α→σ and we might have a solution with \tau =Y \space Fτ=Y F\tau =Y \space Fτ=Y F. But such solution is not available to us. We do not have function from types to types FFFF and a type level Y combinator. However it is ok to construct recursive types (we would do later).
We now show that the representation of the booleans is correct.

If \emptyset \vdash e: \alpha \to ( \alpha \to \alpha )∅⊢e:α→(α→α)\emptyset \vdash e: \alpha \to ( \alpha \to \alpha )∅⊢e:α→(α→α) and eeee is a normal form, then e = \text {true}e=truee = \text {true}e=true or e = \text {false}e=falsee = \text {false}e=false.
We will later combine this with the following theorems which yields correctness of the representation of the booleans.

If \Gamma \vdash e: \tauΓ⊢e:τ\Gamma \vdash e: \tauΓ⊢e:τ then e \to _{ \beta }^*e'e→β∗e′e \to _{ \beta }^*e'e→β∗​e′ for a normal form e'e′e'e′. And we can define subject reduction, if \Gamma \vdash e: \tauΓ⊢e:τ\Gamma \vdash e: \tauΓ⊢e:τ and e \to _{ \beta }e'e→βe′e \to _{ \beta }e'e→β​e′ then \Gamma \vdash e': \tauΓ⊢e′:τ\Gamma \vdash e': \tauΓ⊢e′:τ.

Our characterization of normal forms is quite simple: terms that do not reduce. However, this is a negative condition, which is difficult to work with in proofs. We would like to have a positive condition, which is easier to work with.

We tend to give definitions in the form of inference rules. The property then holds if the judgment can be derived using the rules. (This closely related to the inductive deefintion). Before defining the normal forms we formally define beta reduction. The judgment here e \to e'e→e′e \to e'e→e′ expressing that eeee reduces to e'e′e'e′. \begin {align*} \frac {}{( \lambda x.e_1)e_2 \to e_1[x:=e_2]} ( \text {red/beta}) \\ \frac {e \to e'}{ \lambda x.e \to \lambda x.e'} ( \text {red/lam}) \\ \frac {e_1 \to e_1'}{e_1 \space e_2 \to e_1' \space e_2} ( \text {red/app}_1) \\ \frac {e_2 \to e_2'}{e_1 \space e_2 \to e_1 \space e_2'} ( \text {red/app}_2) \end {align*} (λx.e1)e2→e1[x:=e2](red/beta)e→e′λx.e→λx.e′(red/lam)e1→e1′e1 e2→e1′ e2(red/app1)e2→e2′e1 e2→e1 e2′(red/app2) \begin {align*} \frac {}{( \lambda x.e_1)e_2 \to e_1[x:=e_2]} ( \text {red/beta}) \\ \frac {e \to e'}{ \lambda x.e \to \lambda x.e'} ( \text {red/lam}) \\ \frac {e_1 \to e_1'}{e_1 \space e_2 \to e_1' \space e_2} ( \text {red/app}_1) \\ \frac {e_2 \to e_2'}{e_1 \space e_2 \to e_1 \space e_2'} ( \text {red/app}_2) \end {align*} (λx.e1​)e2​→e1​[x:=e2​]​(red/beta)λx.e→λx.e′e→e′​(red/lam)e1​ e2​→e1′​ e2​e1​→e1′​​(red/app1​)e1​ e2​→e1​ e2′​e2​→e2′​​(red/app2​)​

A normal form is an expression that does not reduce. To give a proper formalization,, we need a separate judgment for neutral terms which do not create a redex when applied to an argument. \begin {align*} \frac {e \text { normal} }{ \lambda x.e \text { normal} } ( \text {normal/lam}) \\ \frac {e \text { neutral} }{e \text { normal} } ( \text {normal/var}) \\ \frac {}{x \text { neutral} } ( \text {neutral/var}) \\ \frac {e_1 \text { neutral} \quad e_2 \text { normal} }{e_1 \space e_2 \text { neutral} } ( \text {neutral/app}) \\ \end {align*} e normalλx.e normal(normal/lam)e neutrale normal(normal/var)x neutral(neutral/var)e1 neutrale2 normale1 e2 neutral(neutral/app) \begin {align*} \frac {e \text { normal} }{ \lambda x.e \text { normal} } ( \text {normal/lam}) \\ \frac {e \text { neutral} }{e \text { normal} } ( \text {normal/var}) \\ \frac {}{x \text { neutral} } ( \text {neutral/var}) \\ \frac {e_1 \text { neutral} \quad e_2 \text { normal} }{e_1 \space e_2 \text { neutral} } ( \text {neutral/app}) \\ \end {align*} λx.e normale normal​(normal/lam)e normale neutral​(normal/var)x neutral​(neutral/var)e1​ e2​ neutrale1​ neutrale2​ normal​(neutral/app)​

The characterization of normal forms via inference rules is compact, but is it really the same as saying that an expression does not reduce? We break this down into the following two properties. For all expressions eeee, either eeee reduces or eeee is normal For all expressions eeee, it is not that case eeee reduces and eeee is normal
We have theorem that ensures that the first property holds. (Proof is omitted).
For every expression eeee, either e \to e'e→e′e \to e'e→e′ for some expression e'e′e'e′ or eeee is a normal form.
I decided to read one paper or article every week. This week's topic is programming language semantics, refer to Graham Huttons's paper Programming language semantics: It's easy as 1,2,3.

Semantics is the general term for the study of meaning. Programming language semantics gives precise mathematical meaning to programs. We use a simple arithmetic expression language (including integers and addition only) to illustrate the basic concepts. This is an example of Occam's razor, a philosophical principle that favours the simplest explanation for a phenomenon.

Now let's define our language of arithmetic expressions built up from the set of integers and the operation of addition. Use a context-free grammar. E: \equiv \mathbb {Z} | E+E E:≡Z∣E+E E: \equiv \mathbb {Z} | E+E E:≡Z∣E+E

An expression is either an integer value or the addition of two sub-expressions. We assume that parentheses can be freely used as required to disambiguate expressions written in normal textual form. This grammar can be easily translated into a Haskell data type.

pre.code: data Expr = Val Integer | Add Expr Expr

mainmatter.p: Now we consider denotational semantics, where the terms in a language is defined using a valuation function that maps terms into values in an appropriate semantic domain.

Formally, for a language TTTT of syntactic terms comprises two components: a set VVVV of semantic values and a valuation function of type T \to VT→VT \to VT→V that maps terms to their meanings as values. This function is written by enclosing a term in a semantic brackets (Also known as Oxford or Strachey brackets), writing \llbracket t \rrbracket⟦t⟧\llbracket t \rrbracket[[t]] for the value of term tttt. In addition, the valuation function is required to be compositional, the meaning of a compound term is defined purely in terms of the meaning of its sub-terms.

Compositionality aids understanding by ensuring that the semantics is modular and supports the use of simple equational reasoning techniques for proving properties of the semantics. When the set of semantic values is clear, a denotational semantics is often identified with the underlying valuation function.

Taking VVVV the Haskell type Integer of integers and define a valuation function of type Expr -> Integer (by following equations) we can define the denotational semantics of our expression language. \begin {align*} \llbracket \text {Val} \space n \rrbracket &= n \\ \llbracket \text {Add} \space e_1 \space e_2 \rrbracket &= \llbracket e_1 \rrbracket + \llbracket e_2 \rrbracket \end {align*} ⟦Val n⟧=n⟦Add e1 e2⟧=⟦e1⟧+⟦e2⟧ \begin {align*} \llbracket \text {Val} \space n \rrbracket &= n \\ \llbracket \text {Add} \space e_1 \space e_2 \rrbracket &= \llbracket e_1 \rrbracket + \llbracket e_2 \rrbracket \end {align*} [[Val n]][[Add e1​ e2​]]​=n=[[e1​]]+[[e2​]]​ This definition satisfies the compositionality requirement obviously. Note that the symbol ++++ has two different purposes. On the left side, it is a syntactic constructor for building terms, while on the right side, it is a semantic operator for adding integers.

Compositionality simplifies reasoning because it allows us to replace equals by equals. For example, \frac { \llbracket e_1 \rrbracket = n_1 \quad \llbracket e_2 \rrbracket = n_2 }{ \llbracket \text {Add} \space e_1 \space e_2 \rrbracket = \llbracket \text {Add} \space n_1 \space n_2 \rrbracket } ⟦e1⟧=n1⟦e2⟧=n2⟦Add e1 e2⟧=⟦Add n1 n2⟧ \frac { \llbracket e_1 \rrbracket = n_1 \quad \llbracket e_2 \rrbracket = n_2 }{ \llbracket \text {Add} \space e_1 \space e_2 \rrbracket = \llbracket \text {Add} \space n_1 \space n_2 \rrbracket } [[Add e1​ e2​]]=[[Add n1​ n2​]][[e1​]]=n1​[[e2​]]=n2​​ we can freely replace the two argument expressions of an addition by other expressions with the same meanings, and the meaning of the whole addition will remain unchanged. Using the definition of the valuation function, we can prove this property. \begin {align*} \llbracket \text {Add} \space e_1 \space e_2 \rrbracket &= \llbracket e_1 \rrbracket + \llbracket e_2 \rrbracket ( \text {By definition of } \llbracket- \rrbracket ) \\ &= \llbracket n_1 \rrbracket + \llbracket n_2 \rrbracket ( \text {Assumptions}) \\ &= \llbracket \text {Add} \space n_1 \space n_2 \rrbracket ( \text {By definition of } \llbracket- \rrbracket ) \end {align*} ⟦Add e1 e2⟧=⟦e1⟧+⟦e2⟧(By definition of ⟦−⟧)=⟦n1⟧+⟦n2⟧(Assumptions)=⟦Add n1 n2⟧(By definition of ⟦−⟧) \begin {align*} \llbracket \text {Add} \space e_1 \space e_2 \rrbracket &= \llbracket e_1 \rrbracket + \llbracket e_2 \rrbracket ( \text {By definition of } \llbracket- \rrbracket ) \\ &= \llbracket n_1 \rrbracket + \llbracket n_2 \rrbracket ( \text {Assumptions}) \\ &= \llbracket \text {Add} \space n_1 \space n_2 \rrbracket ( \text {By definition of } \llbracket- \rrbracket ) \end {align*} [[Add e1​ e2​]]​=[[e1​]]+[[e2​]](By definition of [[−]])=[[n1​]]+[[n2​]](Assumptions)=[[Add n1​ n2​]](By definition of [[−]])​

Given that terms and their semantics are built up inductively, proofs about denotational semantics typically proceed using structural induction. Let us show that our expression semantics is total, that is, for every expression eeee there is an integer nnnn such that \llbracket e \rrbracket = n⟦e⟧=n\llbracket e \rrbracket = n[[e]]=n.

tree.mainmatter: For the base case e = \text {Val} \space ne=Val ne = \text {Val} \space ne=Val n, we have \llbracket e \rrbracket = n⟦e⟧=n\llbracket e \rrbracket = n[[e]]=n trivially. For the inductive case e = \text {Add} \space e_1 \space e_2e=Add e1 e2e = \text {Add} \space e_1 \space e_2e=Add e1​ e2​, we can assume by induction that \llbracket e_1 \rrbracket = n_1⟦e1⟧=n1\llbracket e_1 \rrbracket = n_1[[e1​]]=n1​ and \llbracket e_2 \rrbracket = n_2⟦e2⟧=n2\llbracket e_2 \rrbracket = n_2[[e2​]]=n2​ for some integers n_1n1n_1n1​ and n_2n2n_2n2​. Then \llbracket e \rrbracket = n_1 + n_2⟦e⟧=n1+n2\llbracket e \rrbracket = n_1 + n_2[[e]]=n1​+n2​ by definition of the valuation function, indicates this case is also true. Therefore, the semantics is total.

mainmatter.p: The valuation function can be translated into a Haskell function

pre.code: eval :: Expr -> Integer eval (Val n) = n eval (Add x y) = eval x + eval y

mainmatter.p: More generally, a denotational semantics can be viewed as an evaluator (or interpreter). Even eval is defined recursively, the semantics is compositional its behavior can be understood as simply replacing the constructors for expressions by other functions. In this manner, a denotational semantics can also be viewed as an evaluation function that is defined by folding over the syntax of the source language.

pre.code: eval :: Expr -> Integer eval = fold id (+)

mainmatter.p: The fold operator captures the ideas of replacing constructors of the language by other functions

pre.code: fold :: (Integer -> a) -> (a -> a -> a) -> Expr -> a fold f g (Val n) = f n fold f g (Add x y) = g (fold f g x) (fold f g y)

mainmatter.p: Note that the above semantics for expressions does not specify the order of evaluation. If we do wish to make evaluation order explicit this requires the introduction of additional structure into the semantics, named abstract machines (Discuss later).

Another popular approach to semantics is the operational approach, where the meaning of terms is defined using an execution relation that specifies how terms can be executed in an appropriate machine model. There are two basic forms of operational semantics:
small-step: describes the individual steps of execution
big-step: describes the overall results of execution
In this section we consider the small-step approach, which is also known as structural operational semantics.

Formally, a small-step operational semantics for a language TTTT of syntactic terms comprises two components: a set SSSS of execution states and a transition relation of type S \to SS→SS \to SS→S that specifies how terms can be executed. If there is a transition from state ssss to state s's′s's′ in a single execution step, we write s \to s's→s′s \to s's→s′.

Arithmetic expressions have a simple small-step operational semantics, given by taking SSSS as the Haskell type. And we define transition relation on Expr by the following inference rules. \begin {align*} \frac {}{ \text {Add} \space ( \text {Val} \space n_1) \space ( \text {Val} \space n_2) \to \text {Val} \space (n_1+n_2) } \\ \frac {x \to x'}{ \text {Add} \space x \space y \to \text {Add} \space x' \space y} \quad \frac {y \to y'}{ \text {Add} \space x \space y \to \text {Add} \space x \space y'} \end {align*} Add (Val n1) (Val n2)→Val (n1+n2)x→x′Add x y→Add x′ yy→y′Add x y→Add x y′ \begin {align*} \frac {}{ \text {Add} \space ( \text {Val} \space n_1) \space ( \text {Val} \space n_2) \to \text {Val} \space (n_1+n_2) } \\ \frac {x \to x'}{ \text {Add} \space x \space y \to \text {Add} \space x' \space y} \quad \frac {y \to y'}{ \text {Add} \space x \space y \to \text {Add} \space x \space y'} \end {align*} Add (Val n1​) (Val n2​)→Val (n1​+n2​)​Add x y→Add x′ yx→x′​Add x y→Add x y′y→y′​​

The first rule states that two values can be added to give a single value and is called a reduction (or contraction) rule. An expression that matches such a rule is termed a reducible expression or redex. The last two rules are called structural (or congruence) rules as they specify how larger terms can be reduced.

The semantics is non-deterministic because an expression may have more than one possible transition. This is obviously from the structural rules, which allow either sub-expression to be reduced first.

We can now capture a the relation between the denotational and operational semantics, namely that making a transition does not change the denotation of an expression. \frac { e \to e' }{ \llbracket e \rrbracket = \llbracket e' \rrbracket } e→e′⟦e⟧=⟦e′⟧ \frac { e \to e' }{ \llbracket e \rrbracket = \llbracket e' \rrbracket } [[e]]=[[e′]]e→e′​ This property can be proved by induction on the structure of the expression eeee. Note that by using the "equals by equals" and the assumption x \to x'x→x′x \to x'x→x′ we can easily prove the inductive case. The details are omitted here as it involves quite a bit of case analysis. We will later see the principle of rule induction, which gives a simpler and more direct way to prove such properties.

Evaluation of an expression using the small-step semantics proceeds by a series of zero or more transition steps. Formally we can write e \to ^* e'e→∗e′e \to ^* e'e→∗e′ to indicate that eeee can be reduced to e'e′e'e′ in zero or more steps. We can generate a transition tree that captures all possible execution paths for an expression. Using the list comprehension we can define a function that returns the list of all expressions that can be reduced from a given expression eeee in a single transition.

pre.code: trans :: Expr -> [Expr] trans (Val n) = [] trans (Add (Val n) (Val m)) = [Val (n + m)] trans (Add x y) = [Add x' y | x' <- trans x] ++ [Add x y' | y' <- trans y]

mainmatter.p: We can define a Haskell datatype for transition trees and an execution function that converts expressions into transition trees.

pre.code: data Tree a = Node a [Tree a] exec :: Expr -> Tree Expr exec e = Node e [exec e' | e' <- trans e]

mainmatter.p: Though exec is defined recursively, its behavior can be understood as simply applying the identity function to give the root of the tree and the transition function to generate a list of residual expressions to be processed to give the subtrees. A small-step semantics can be viewed as giving rise to an execution function that is defined by unfolding to transition trees.

pre.code: exec :: Expr -> Tree Expr exec = unfold id trans

mainmatter.p: The unfold function captures the idea of generating a tree from a seed value xxxx by applying a function ffff to give the root and a function gggg to give a list of residual values to be processed for the subtrees.

pre.code: unfold :: (t -> a) -> (t -> [t]) -> t -> Tree a unfold f g x = Node (f x) [unfold f g x' | x' <- g x]

mainmatter.p: The operational semantics corresponds to unfolding to transition trees, while denotational semantics corresponds to folding over syntax trees. Thinking about semantics in terms of recursion operators reveals a duality

The above semantics for expressions does not specify the order of evaluation. But we can modify the inference rules to achieve this. Replace the second \text {Add}Add\text {Add}Add rule by the following rule ensures the first argument of addition is always reduced first. \frac { y \to y' }{ \text {Add} ( \text {Val} \space n) \space y \to \text {Add} ( \text {Val} \space n) \space y' } y→y′Add(Val n) y→Add(Val n) y′ \frac { y \to y' }{ \text {Add} ( \text {Val} \space n) \space y \to \text {Add} ( \text {Val} \space n) \space y' } Add(Val n) y→Add(Val n) y′y→y′​

For denotational semantics we have structural induction, dual to this, for operational semantics we have rule induction. This allows us to perform proofs by considering the structure of the rules that are used to define the semantics.

We introduce the idea of rule induction using a simple numeric example. We begin by inductively defining a set of natural numbers. \frac {}{0 \in \mathbb {N} } \quad \frac {n \in \mathbb {N} }{n+1 \in \mathbb {N} } 0∈Nn∈Nn+1∈N \frac {}{0 \in \mathbb {N} } \quad \frac {n \in \mathbb {N} }{n+1 \in \mathbb {N} } 0∈N​n+1∈Nn∈N​ This is the standard definition of the natural numbers using peano axioms, where the first rule states that zero is a natural number and the second rule states that if nnnn is a natural number then so is n+1n+1n+1n+1.

For the inductively defined set \mathbb {N}N\mathbb {N}N. The principle of rule induction states that in order to prove a property P(n)P(n)P(n)P(n) for all natural numbers nnnn, it suffices to prove that P(0)P(0)P(0)P(0) holds and that if P(n)P(n)P(n)P(n) holds then P(n+1)P(n+1)P(n+1)P(n+1) holds. \frac { P(0) \quad \forall n \in \mathbb {N} . P(n) \to P(n+1) }{ \forall n \in \mathbb {N} . P(n) } P(0)∀n∈N.P(n)→P(n+1)∀n∈N.P(n) \frac { P(0) \quad \forall n \in \mathbb {N} . P(n) \to P(n+1) }{ \forall n \in \mathbb {N} . P(n) } ∀n∈N.P(n)P(0)∀n∈N.P(n)→P(n+1)​ Notice that this is the well-known principle of mathematical induction.

The concept of rule induction can easily be generalised to multiple base and inductive cases, to rule with multiple preconditions and so on. For the small-step semantics of expressions, we have one base case and two inductive cases. Hence if we want to show that some property P(e,e')P(e,e′)P(e,e')P(e,e′) on pairs of expression holds for all transition e \to e'e→e′e \to e'e→e′, we can use rule induction: \frac { \begin {align*} P( \text {Add} \space ( \text {Val} \space n_1) \space ( \text {Val} \space n_2), \text {Val} \space (n_1+n_2)) \\ \forall x \to x'. P(x,x') \to P( \text {Add} \space x \space y, \text {Add} \space x' \space y) \\ \forall y \to y'. P(y,y') \to P( \text {Add} \space x \space y, \text {Add} \space x \space y') \end {align*} }{ \forall e \to e'. P(e,e') } P(Add (Val n1) (Val n2),Val (n1+n2))∀x→x′.P(x,x′)→P(Add x y,Add x′ y)∀y→y′.P(y,y′)→P(Add x y,Add x y′)∀e→e′.P(e,e′) \frac { \begin {align*} P( \text {Add} \space ( \text {Val} \space n_1) \space ( \text {Val} \space n_2), \text {Val} \space (n_1+n_2)) \\ \forall x \to x'. P(x,x') \to P( \text {Add} \space x \space y, \text {Add} \space x' \space y) \\ \forall y \to y'. P(y,y') \to P( \text {Add} \space x \space y, \text {Add} \space x \space y') \end {align*} }{ \forall e \to e'. P(e,e') } ∀e→e′.P(e,e′)P(Add (Val n1​) (Val n2​),Val (n1​+n2​))∀x→x′.P(x,x′)→P(Add x y,Add x′ y)∀y→y′.P(y,y′)→P(Add x y,Add x y′)​​ We write \forall x \to y.P(x,y)∀x→y.P(x,y)\forall x \to y.P(x,y)∀x→y.P(x,y) as shorthand for \forall x,y.x \to y \Rightarrow P(x,y)∀x,y.x→y⇒P(x,y)\forall x,y.x \to y \Rightarrow P(x,y)∀x,y.x→y⇒P(x,y). Now we give the proof of the property \llbracket e \rrbracket = \llbracket e' \rrbracket⟦e⟧=⟦e′⟧\llbracket e \rrbracket = \llbracket e' \rrbracket[[e]]=[[e′]] for all transitions e \to e'e→e′e \to e'e→e′. \forall e \to e'. \llbracket e \rrbracket = \llbracket e' \rrbracket ∀e→e′.⟦e⟧=⟦e′⟧ \forall e \to e'. \llbracket e \rrbracket = \llbracket e' \rrbracket ∀e→e′.[[e]]=[[e′]]

tree.mainmatter: The proof consists of three parts: the base case, the reduction rule and the structural rule. \begin {align*} \llbracket \text {Add} \space ( \text {Val} \space n) \space ( \text {Val} \space m) \rrbracket &= \llbracket \text {Val} \space n \rrbracket + \llbracket \text {Val} \space m \rrbracket \\ &= n + m \\ &= \llbracket \text {Val} \space (n+m) \rrbracket \end {align*} ⟦Add (Val n) (Val m)⟧=⟦Val n⟧+⟦Val m⟧=n+m=⟦Val (n+m)⟧ \begin {align*} \llbracket \text {Add} \space ( \text {Val} \space n) \space ( \text {Val} \space m) \rrbracket &= \llbracket \text {Val} \space n \rrbracket + \llbracket \text {Val} \space m \rrbracket \\ &= n + m \\ &= \llbracket \text {Val} \space (n+m) \rrbracket \end {align*} [[Add (Val n) (Val m)]]​=[[Val n]]+[[Val m]]=n+m=[[Val (n+m)]]​ and \begin {align*} \llbracket \text {Add} \space x \space y \rrbracket &= \llbracket x \rrbracket + \llbracket y \rrbracket \\ &= \llbracket x' \rrbracket + \llbracket y \rrbracket ( \text {By assumption } \llbracket x \rrbracket = \llbracket x' \rrbracket ) \\ &= \llbracket \text {Add} \space x' \space y \rrbracket \end {align*} ⟦Add x y⟧=⟦x⟧+⟦y⟧=⟦x′⟧+⟦y⟧(By assumption ⟦x⟧=⟦x′⟧)=⟦Add x′ y⟧ \begin {align*} \llbracket \text {Add} \space x \space y \rrbracket &= \llbracket x \rrbracket + \llbracket y \rrbracket \\ &= \llbracket x' \rrbracket + \llbracket y \rrbracket ( \text {By assumption } \llbracket x \rrbracket = \llbracket x' \rrbracket ) \\ &= \llbracket \text {Add} \space x' \space y \rrbracket \end {align*} [[Add x y]]​=[[x]]+[[y]]=[[x′]]+[[y]](By assumption [[x]]=[[x′]])=[[Add x′ y]]​ and \begin {align*} \llbracket \text {Add} \space x \space y \rrbracket &= \llbracket x \rrbracket + \llbracket y \rrbracket \\ &= \llbracket x \rrbracket + \llbracket y' \rrbracket ( \text {By assumption } \llbracket y \rrbracket = \llbracket y' \rrbracket ) \\ &= \llbracket \text {Add} \space x \space y' \rrbracket \end {align*} ⟦Add x y⟧=⟦x⟧+⟦y⟧=⟦x⟧+⟦y′⟧(By assumption ⟦y⟧=⟦y′⟧)=⟦Add x y′⟧ \begin {align*} \llbracket \text {Add} \space x \space y \rrbracket &= \llbracket x \rrbracket + \llbracket y \rrbracket \\ &= \llbracket x \rrbracket + \llbracket y' \rrbracket ( \text {By assumption } \llbracket y \rrbracket = \llbracket y' \rrbracket ) \\ &= \llbracket \text {Add} \space x \space y' \rrbracket \end {align*} [[Add x y]]​=[[x]]+[[y]]=[[x]]+[[y′]](By assumption [[y]]=[[y′]])=[[Add x y′]]​

mainmatter.p: The small-step semantics for expressions above has one basic reduction rule for adding values and two structural rules that allow addition to be performed in larger expressions. Separating these two kinds of rules results the notion of contextual semantics (or reduction semantics).

Informally, a context in this setting is a term with a "hole", usually written as [-][−][-][−], which can be filled with another term later. In a contextual semantics, the hole represents the location where a single basic step of execution may take place within a term.

Consider the following transition in our small-step semantics. (1+2)+(3+4) \to 3+(3+4) (1+2)+(3+4)→3+(3+4) (1+2)+(3+4) \to 3+(3+4) (1+2)+(3+4)→3+(3+4) The addition is performed on the left side. We say that we can perform the basic step 1+2 \to31+2→31+2 \to31+2→3 in the context [-] +(3+4)[−]+(3+4)[-] +(3+4)[−]+(3+4) where [-][−][-][−] implies the location of the addition takes place.

The language CCCC of contexts of arithmetic expressions can be formally defined by C: \equiv [-] |C+E|E+C C:≡[−]∣C+E∣E+C C: \equiv [-] |C+E|E+C C:≡[−]∣C+E∣E+C As previously, we can define a Haskell datatype for contexts.

pre.code: data Cont = Hole | Add Cont Expr | Add Expr Cont

mainmatter.p: The kind of context is known as "outside-in" as locating the hole involves navigating from the outside of the context inwards. To fill the hole in a context cccc with an expression eeee we write c \space [e]c [e]c \space [e]c [e]: \begin {align*} \text {Hole} \space [e] &= e \\ ( \text {AddL} \space c \space r ) \space [e] &= \text {Add} \space (c \space [e]) \space r \\ ( \text {AddR} \space l \space c ) \space [e] &= \text {Add} \space l \space (c \space [e]) \end {align*} Hole [e]=e(AddL c r) [e]=Add (c [e]) r(AddR l c) [e]=Add l (c [e]) \begin {align*} \text {Hole} \space [e] &= e \\ ( \text {AddL} \space c \space r ) \space [e] &= \text {Add} \space (c \space [e]) \space r \\ ( \text {AddR} \space l \space c ) \space [e] &= \text {Add} \space l \space (c \space [e]) \end {align*} Hole [e](AddL c r) [e](AddR l c) [e]​=e=Add (c [e]) r=Add l (c [e])​

Use the idea of hole filling we can redefine the small-step semantics for expressions in contextual style. \frac {}{ \text {Add} \space ( \text {Val} \space n_1) \space ( \text {Val} \space n_2) \rightarrowtail \text {Val} \space (n_1+n_2) } \quad \frac { e \rightarrowtail e' }{ c \space [e] \to c \space [e'] } Add (Val n1) (Val n2)↣Val (n1+n2)e↣e′c [e]→c [e′] \frac {}{ \text {Add} \space ( \text {Val} \space n_1) \space ( \text {Val} \space n_2) \rightarrowtail \text {Val} \space (n_1+n_2) } \quad \frac { e \rightarrowtail e' }{ c \space [e] \to c \space [e'] } Add (Val n1​) (Val n2​)↣Val (n1​+n2​)​c [e]→c [e′]e↣e′​ This first rule defines a reduction relation \rightarrowtail↣\rightarrowtail↣ that captures the basic behavior of addition, while the second defines a transition relation \to→\to→ that allows the first rule to be applied in any context.

We have now refactored the small-step semantics into a single reduction rule and a single structural rule. If we subsequently want to extend the language with other features, it only requires adding new reduction rules and extending the notion of contexts but not need to adding new structural rules.
Now we define the hole filling function in Haskell.

pre.code: fill :: Cont -> Expr -> Expr fill Hole e = e fill (AddL c r) e = Add (fill c e) r fill (AddR l c) e = Add l (fill c e)

mainmatter.p: The dual operation which splits an expression into all possible pairs of contexts and expressions can be defined:

pre.code: split :: Expr -> [(Cont,Expr)] split e = (Hole, e) : case e of Val n -> [] Add l r -> [(AddL c r, x) | (c, x) <- split l] ++ [(AddR l c, x) | (c, x) <- split r]

mainmatter.p: A pair (c,x)(c,x)(c,x)(c,x) comprising a context #[c] and an expression xxxx is an element of the list returned by split e precisely when fill c x = e. The contextual semantics can be translated into Haskell function that returns the lists of all expressions that can be reached by performing a single reduction step.

pre.code: reduce :: Expr -> [Expr] reduce (Add (Val n) (Val m)) = [Val (n + m)] reduce _ = []

mainmatter.p: or a single transition step.

pre.code: trans :: Expr -> [Expr] trans e = [fill c x' | (c, x) <- split e, x' <- reduce x]

mainmatter.p: This function splits the given expression into all possible context and expression pairs, then considering any reduction that can made by each component expression, and finally filling the hole in the context with the reduced expression.

Notice that the contextual semantics does not specify an evaluation order for addition and is non-deterministic. We can modify the language of contexts to achieve so. C: \equiv [-] |C+E| \mathbb {Z} +C C:≡[−]∣C+E∣Z+C C: \equiv [-] |C+E| \mathbb {Z} +C C:≡[−]∣C+E∣Z+C This version of the semantics also satisfies a unique decomposition property, that is, any expression eeee that is not a value can be uniquely decomposed into the form e=c \space [x]e=c [x]e=c \space [x]e=c [x] for some context cccc and reducible expression xxxx. This can be proved by induction on the expression eeee.
Contexts are related to a number of other important concepts in programming and semantics, including the use of continuations to make control flow explicit (John C. Reynolds 1972).

Big-step semantics is also known as natural semantics, which focus on large execution step. For a language T of syntactic terms comprises two components: a set VVVV of values and an evaluation relation between TTTT and VVVV that relates each term to all values that can be reached by fully executing the term. If a term tttt and a value vvvv are related, we say that tttt can evaluate to vvvv and write this as t \Downarrow vt⇓vt \Downarrow vt⇓v
mainmatter.tex: \frac {}{ \text {Val} \space n \Downarrow n } \quad \frac { x \Downarrow n \quad y \Downarrow m }{ \text {Add} \space x \space y \Downarrow n+m } Val n⇓nx⇓ny⇓mAdd x y⇓n+m \frac {}{ \text {Val} \space n \Downarrow n } \quad \frac { x \Downarrow n \quad y \Downarrow m }{ \text {Add} \space x \space y \Downarrow n+m } Val n⇓n​Add x y⇓n+mx⇓ny⇓m​
mainmatter.p: The Haskell function definition is similar to the small-step semantics, by using the list comprehension.

pre.code: eval :: Expr -> [Integer] eval (Val n) = [n] eval (Add x y) = [n + m | n <- eval x, m <- eval y]

mainmatter.p: This is similar to denotational semantics but using inference rules rather than a functional manner. However, there is no need for a big-step semantics to be compositional. Formally, the denotational and big-step semantics for the expression language are equivalent, which can be captured by the following property: \llbracket e \rrbracket = n \iff e \Downarrow n ⟦e⟧=n  ⟺  e⇓n \llbracket e \rrbracket = n \iff e \Downarrow n [[e]]=n⟺e⇓n This is easily verified by induction.

All the exmaples we have meet focused on explaining semantic ideas, now we show how language of integers and addition can also be used to help discover semantic ideas. We show how it can be used as the basis for discovering how to implement an abstract machine.
Remember the evaluation order problem we meet before, if we want to make evaluation order explicit, we can introduce additional structure into the semantics by constructing an abstract machine.

Formally, an abstract machine is usually deifned by a set of syntactic rewrite ruless that make explicit how each step of evaluation proceeds. This section we show how an abstract machine for our example language can be systematically derived from the evaluation function using steps based on two important semantic concepts, continuations and defunctionalisation.
We want to make the order of evaluation explicit in the semantics itself. A standard technique for achieving this aim is to rewrite the semantics in continuation-passing style.

In our setting, a continuation is a function that will be applied to the result of an evaluation. Formally, for our semantics eval :: Expr -> Integer, a continuation is a function of type Integer -> Integer that will be applied to the resulting integer to give a new integer. (This type can be generalized to Integer -> a, but we do not need now) We capture the notion of such a continuation using the following type declaration:

pre.code: type Continuation = Integer -> Integer

mainmatter.p: We now define a new semantics \text {eval}'eval′\text {eval}'eval′, which takes an expression and returns an integer as previously but also takes a continuation as an additional argument, which is applied to the result of evaluating the expression.

pre.code: eval' :: Expr -> Continuation -> Integer

mainmatter.p: The behavior of \text {eval}'eval′\text {eval}'eval′ should be:
mainmatter.tex: \text {eval}' \space e \space c = \text {c (eval e)} eval′ e c=c (eval e) \text {eval}' \space e \space c = \text {c (eval e)} eval′ e c=c (eval e)
mainmatter.p: We want to calculate a definition that satisfies the specification. Using structural induction on the expression eeee, we construct the term \text {eval}' \space e \space ceval′ e c\text {eval}' \space e \space ceval′ e c by gradually removing the reference to eval. For the base case, e = \text {Val} \space ne=Val ne = \text {Val} \space ne=Val n we have
mainmatter.tex: \begin {align*} \text {eval}' \space ( \text {Val} \space n) \space c &= c \space ( \text {eval} \space ( \text {Val} \space n)) \\ &= c \space n \end {align*} eval′ (Val n) c=c (eval (Val n))=c n \begin {align*} \text {eval}' \space ( \text {Val} \space n) \space c &= c \space ( \text {eval} \space ( \text {Val} \space n)) \\ &= c \space n \end {align*} eval′ (Val n) c​=c (eval (Val n))=c n​
mainmatter.p: For the inductive case, e = \text {Add} \space x \space ye=Add x ye = \text {Add} \space x \space ye=Add x y we begin in the same way:
mainmatter.tex: \begin {align*} \text {eval}' \space ( \text {Add} \space x \space y) \space c &= c \space ( \text {eval} \space ( \text {Add} \space x \space y)) \\ &= c \space ( \text {eval} \space x + \text {eval} \space y) \end {align*} eval′ (Add x y) c=c (eval (Add x y))=c (eval x+eval y) \begin {align*} \text {eval}' \space ( \text {Add} \space x \space y) \space c &= c \space ( \text {eval} \space ( \text {Add} \space x \space y)) \\ &= c \space ( \text {eval} \space x + \text {eval} \space y) \end {align*} eval′ (Add x y) c​=c (eval (Add x y))=c (eval x+eval y)​
mainmatter.p: However, no further definition can be applied now, so we consider the inductive hypothesis: Forall c'c′c'c′ and c''c′′c''c′′ we have \text {eval}' \space x \space c' = c'( \text {eval} \space x)eval′ x c′=c′(eval x)\text {eval}' \space x \space c' = c'( \text {eval} \space x)eval′ x c′=c′(eval x) and \text {eval}' \space y \space c'' = c''( \text {eval} \space y)eval′ y c′′=c′′(eval y)\text {eval}' \space y \space c'' = c''( \text {eval} \space y)eval′ y c′′=c′′(eval y). This can readily be achieved by abstracting over \text {eval} \space xeval x\text {eval} \space xeval x and \text {eval} \space yeval y\text {eval} \space yeval y using lambda abstraction.
mainmatter.tex: \begin {align*} & c \space ( \text {eval} \space x + \text {eval} \space y) \\ =& ( \lambda n \to c \space (n+ \text {eval} \space y)) \\ =& \text {eval}' \space x \space ( \lambda n \to c \space (n+ \text {eval} \space y)) \\ =& \text {eval}' \space x \space ( \lambda n \to ( \lambda m \to c \space (n+m))( \text {eval} \space y)) \\ =& \text {eval}' \space x \space ( \lambda n \to \text {eval}' \space y \space ( \lambda m \to c \space (n+m))) \end {align*} c (eval x+eval y)=(λn→c (n+eval y))=eval′ x (λn→c (n+eval y))=eval′ x (λn→(λm→c (n+m))(eval y))=eval′ x (λn→eval′ y (λm→c (n+m))) \begin {align*} & c \space ( \text {eval} \space x + \text {eval} \space y) \\ =& ( \lambda n \to c \space (n+ \text {eval} \space y)) \\ =& \text {eval}' \space x \space ( \lambda n \to c \space (n+ \text {eval} \space y)) \\ =& \text {eval}' \space x \space ( \lambda n \to ( \lambda m \to c \space (n+m))( \text {eval} \space y)) \\ =& \text {eval}' \space x \space ( \lambda n \to \text {eval}' \space y \space ( \lambda m \to c \space (n+m))) \end {align*} ====​c (eval x+eval y)(λn→c (n+eval y))eval′ x (λn→c (n+eval y))eval′ x (λn→(λm→c (n+m))(eval y))eval′ x (λn→eval′ y (λm→c (n+m)))​
mainmatter.p: The final term does not refer to \text {eval}eval\text {eval}eval now. In summary we have calculated the following definition

pre.code: eval' :: Expr -> Continuation -> Integer eval' (Val n) c = c n eval' (Add x y) c = eval' x (\n -> eval' y (\m -> c (n + m)))

mainmatter.p: Our original semantics can be recovered from the new semantics by using the identity continuation \lambda n \to nλn→n\lambda n \to nλn→n

pre.code: eval e = eval' e (\n -> n)

mainmatter.p: We use continuation to make the order of evaluation explicit in the semantics, but this also makes the semantics into a higher-order function. Hence our second step is to regain the first-order nature of the original semantics by eliminating the use of continuations but retaining the explicit order of evaluation they introduced.

A standard technique for eliminating the use of functions as arguments is defunctionalisation. We do not usually need the entire function-space of possible argument functions, there only a few forms of such functions are actually used. Hence we represent the argument functions that we actually need using a datatype rather than functions.
We begin by defining three combinators halt, next and add for constructing the continuations we used.

pre.code:
halt :: Continuation halt n = n
next :: Expr -> Continuation -> Continuation next y c = \n -> eval' y (add n c)
add :: Integer -> Continuation -> Continuation add n c = \m -> c (n + m)

mainmatter.p: Use the combinators, our continuation semantics can now be written as:

pre.code:
eval :: Expr -> Integer eavl e = eval' e halt
eval' :: Expr -> Continuation -> Integer eval' (Val n) c = c n eval' (Add x y) c = eval' x (next y c)

mainmatter.p: Now we declare a new datatype for continuations, consists of three constructors.

pre.code: data CONT = HALT | NEXT Expr CONT | ADD Integer CONT

mainmatter.p: The following translation function forms a denotational semantics for CONT

pre.code: exec :: CONT -> Continuation exec HALT = halt exec (NEXT y c) = next y (exec c) exec (ADD n c) = add n (exec c)

mainmatter.p: This function is usually called apply, which can be viewed as applying a representation of a continuation to an integer to give another integer. We want to define a new semantics \text {eval}'eval′\text {eval}'eval′ which behaves in the same way as our previous \text {eval}'eval′\text {eval}'eval′ except that it uses values of type CONT rather than Continuation. eval'' :: Expr -> CONT -> Integer The desired behavior of \text {eval}''eval′′\text {eval}''eval′′ is: \text {eval}'' \space e \space c = \text {eval}' \space e \space ( \text {exec} \space c) eval′′ e c=eval′ e (exec c) \text {eval}'' \space e \space c = \text {eval}' \space e \space ( \text {exec} \space c) eval′′ e c=eval′ e (exec c)

As before, we proceed by structural induction on expression eeee. The base case e= \text {Val} \space ne=Val ne= \text {Val} \space ne=Val n is trivial \begin {align*} \text {eval}'' \space ( \text {Val} \space n) \space c &= \text {eval}' \space ( \text {Val} \space n) \space ( \text {exec} \space c) \\ &= \text {exec} \space c \space n \\ \end {align*} eval′′ (Val n) c=eval′ (Val n) (exec c)=exec c n \begin {align*} \text {eval}'' \space ( \text {Val} \space n) \space c &= \text {eval}' \space ( \text {Val} \space n) \space ( \text {exec} \space c) \\ &= \text {exec} \space c \space n \\ \end {align*} eval′′ (Val n) c​=eval′ (Val n) (exec c)=exec c n​

For the inductive case e = \text {Add} \space x \space ye=Add x ye = \text {Add} \space x \space ye=Add x y: \begin {align*} \text {eval}'' \space ( \text {Add} \space x \space y) \space c &= \text {eval}' \space ( \text {Add} \space x \space y) \space ( \text {exec} \space c) \\ &= \text {eval}' \space x \space ( \text {next} \space y \space ( \text {exec} \space c)) \\ &= \text {eval}' \space x \space ( \text {exec} \space ( \text {NEXT} \space y \space c)) \\ &= \text {eval}'' \space x \space ( \text {NEXT} \space y \space c) \end {align*} eval′′ (Add x y) c=eval′ (Add x y) (exec c)=eval′ x (next y (exec c))=eval′ x (exec (NEXT y c))=eval′′ x (NEXT y c) \begin {align*} \text {eval}'' \space ( \text {Add} \space x \space y) \space c &= \text {eval}' \space ( \text {Add} \space x \space y) \space ( \text {exec} \space c) \\ &= \text {eval}' \space x \space ( \text {next} \space y \space ( \text {exec} \space c)) \\ &= \text {eval}' \space x \space ( \text {exec} \space ( \text {NEXT} \space y \space c)) \\ &= \text {eval}'' \space x \space ( \text {NEXT} \space y \space c) \end {align*} eval′′ (Add x y) c​=eval′ (Add x y) (exec c)=eval′ x (next y (exec c))=eval′ x (exec (NEXT y c))=eval′′ x (NEXT y c)​ The last step uses the inductive hypothesis for xxxx

In the basic case, \text {exec}exec\text {exec}exec still refers to the semantic \text {eval}'eval′\text {eval}'eval′, via the combinator \text {next}next\text {next}next. Hence we need to compute a new definition for \text {exec}exec\text {exec}exec that refers to our new \text {eval}''eval′′\text {eval}''eval′′.
mainmatter.tex: \begin {align*} \text {exec} \space \text {HALT} \space n &= \text {halt} \space n \\ &= n \end {align*} exec HALT n=halt n=n \begin {align*} \text {exec} \space \text {HALT} \space n &= \text {halt} \space n \\ &= n \end {align*} exec HALT n​=halt n=n​
mainmatter.p: The other case is also easy to compute, no need to induction.
mainmatter.tex: \begin {align*} \text {exec} \space ( \text {NEXT} \space y \space c) \space n &= \text {eval}'' \space y \space ( \text {ADD} \space n \space c) \\ \text {exec} \space ( \text {ADD} \space n \space c) \space m &= \text {exec} \space c \space (n+m) \end {align*} exec (NEXT y c) n=eval′′ y (ADD n c)exec (ADD n c) m=exec c (n+m) \begin {align*} \text {exec} \space ( \text {NEXT} \space y \space c) \space n &= \text {eval}'' \space y \space ( \text {ADD} \space n \space c) \\ \text {exec} \space ( \text {ADD} \space n \space c) \space m &= \text {exec} \space c \space (n+m) \end {align*} exec (NEXT y c) nexec (ADD n c) m​=eval′′ y (ADD n c)=exec c (n+m)​
mainmatter.p: Our original semantics \text {eval}eval\text {eval}eval can be recovered from the new semantics \text {eval}''eval′′\text {eval}''eval′′ too.
mainmatter.tex: \begin {align*} \text {eval} \space e &= \text {eval}' \space e \space ( \lambda n \to n) \\ &= \text {eval}' \space e \space \text {halt} \\ &= \text {eval}' \space e \space ( \text {exec} \space \text {HALT} ) \\ &= \text {eval}'' \space e \text {HALT} \end {align*} eval e=eval′ e (λn→n)=eval′ e halt=eval′ e (exec HALT)=eval′′ eHALT \begin {align*} \text {eval} \space e &= \text {eval}' \space e \space ( \lambda n \to n) \\ &= \text {eval}' \space e \space \text {halt} \\ &= \text {eval}' \space e \space ( \text {exec} \space \text {HALT} ) \\ &= \text {eval}'' \space e \text {HALT} \end {align*} eval e​=eval′ e (λn→n)=eval′ e halt=eval′ e (exec HALT)=eval′′ eHALT​
mainmatter.p: In summary, we have calculated the following definitions:

pre.code:
eval'' :: Expr -> CONT -> Integer eval'' (Val n) c = exec c n eval'' (Add x y) c = eval'' x (NEXT y c)
exec :: CONT -> Integer -> Integer exec HALT n = n exec (NEXT y c) n = eval'' y (ADD n c) exec (ADD n c) m = exec c (n + m)
eval :: Expr -> Integer eval e = eval'' e HALT

mainmatter.p: The four components (\text {eval}''eval′′\text {eval}''eval′′, \text {eval}eval\text {eval}eval, \text {exec}exec\text {exec}exec and CONT) forms an abstract machine.

CONT is the type of control stack which comprises instructions that determine how the machine should continue after evaluating the current expression. Sometimes it is called an "eval/continue" machine. The control stack can also be defined as a list of instructions.
type CONT = [INST] data INST = NEXT Expr | ADD Integer
\text {eval}eval\text {eval}eval evaluates an expression and give an integer by simply call the \text {eval}''eval′′\text {eval}''eval′′ with empty control stack \text {HALT}HALT\text {HALT}HALT.

\text {eval}''eval′′\text {eval}''eval′′ evaluates an expression in the context of a control stack. If the expression is an integer, we execute the control stack using this integer as an argument. If the expression is an addition, we evaluate the first argument xxxx and place the instruction \text {NEXT} \space yNEXT y\text {NEXT} \space yNEXT y on the top of the control stack.

\text {exec}exec\text {exec}exec executes the control stack. If the control stack is empty, then just return the integer argument as the result. If the top instruction is \text {NEXT} \space yNEXT y\text {NEXT} \space yNEXT y, we evaluate yyyy and place the instruction \text {ADD} \space nADD n\text {ADD} \space nADD n to the stack top. If the top instruction is \text {ADD} \space nADD n\text {ADD} \space nADD n,evaluation of the two arguments of an addition is complete, and we execute the remaining control stack in the context of the sum of the resulting integers.
This is a collection of notes on categorical semantics for type theories. The notes are based on the paper by Jason Z.S. Hu and NLab.

Over the last few decades, many type systems are designed for different purposes: general program safety, security, and correctness. The categorical semantics is a collection of methods which define meanings of types and programs in category theory.

Category theory is a branch of mathematics studying an abstract kind of mappings, called morphisms, and their algebraic relations. Its generality serves as a common language for navigating connections between different concepts in different areas. We will first go over some basic concepts in category theory.
Formally, a definition in category theory consists of two parts: data and axioms. The most basic definition is the category

mainmatter.p: We only talk about collections here, which is vague, because we do not specify they are sets or classes. If both objects and morphisms fit in sets, we say the category is small. For a counterexample, the category of all sets is not small. However, all functions between sets can be contained in a set. In this case, the category is locally small. When morphisms between two objects fit in a set, we call the set hom-set.

Since category theory is constructed to study structures and a category is actually a structure, we can talk about the category of all small categories \mathbf {Cat}Cat\mathbf {Cat}Cat. Similar to morphisms, we can define functor between categories.

A functor FFFF from a category CCCC to a category DDDD is a map sending each x \in Cx∈Cx \in Cx∈C to an object F(x) \in DF(x)∈DF(x) \in DF(x)∈D and each morphism f:x \to yf:x→yf:x \to yf:x→y in CCCC to morphism F(f):F(x) \to F(y)F(f):F(x)→F(y)F(f):F(x) \to F(y)F(f):F(x)→F(y) in DDDD, such that Composition is preserved: F(g \circ f) = F(g) \circ F(f)F(g∘f)=F(g)∘F(f)F(g \circ f) = F(g) \circ F(f)F(g∘f)=F(g)∘F(f). Identity is preserved: F( \text {id} _x) = \text {id} _{F(x)}F(idx)=idF(x)F( \text {id} _x) = \text {id} _{F(x)}F(idx​)=idF(x)​.
We can push this idea further by considering functors as objects and natural transformations as morphisms.

Let CCCC and DDDD be categories, the functor category D^CDCD^CDC (or [C,D][C,D][C,D][C,D]) is the category whose objects are functors from CCCC to DDDD. morphisms are natural transformations between functors.

Here we use a commutative diagram to represent a natural transformation. When a diagram commutes, morphisms composed by different paths with the same end points are equal. The following diagram represents the equality that G(f) \circ \alpha _x = \alpha _y \circ F(f)G(f)∘αx=αy∘F(f)G(f) \circ \alpha _x = \alpha _y \circ F(f)G(f)∘αx​=αy​∘F(f).

Though the theory is already rich by only considering sets and categories, it would not be interesting enough. We want to know a little more about the category that we are working with. To achieve so, we can require some additional structures on the category. A common structure is the cartesian product.

Given any category \mathcal {C}C\mathcal {C}C, and any set \{ X_i \} _{i \in I}{Xi}i∈I\{ X_i \} _{i \in I}{Xi​}i∈I​ of its objects, the product of all these objects is, if it exists, an object \prod _{i \in I} X_i \in \mathcal {C} ∏i∈IXi∈C \prod _{i \in I} X_i \in \mathcal {C} ∏i∈I​Xi​∈C equipped with morphisms (projections) p_i : \left ( \prod _{i \in I} X_i \right ) \to X_i pi:(∏i∈IXi)→Xi p_i : \left ( \prod _{i \in I} X_i \right ) \to X_i pi​:(i∈I∏​Xi​)→Xi​ for each i \in Ii∈Ii \in Ii∈I, such that it is universal with this property, i.e. such that given any other object Q \in CQ∈CQ \in CQ∈C with morphisms Q \xrightarrow {f_i} X_i Q→fiXi Q \xrightarrow {f_i} X_i Qfi​​Xi​ there is a unique morphism (f_i)_{i \in I} : Q \to \prod _{i \in I} X_i (fi)i∈I:Q→∏i∈IXi (f_i)_{i \in I} : Q \to \prod _{i \in I} X_i (fi​)i∈I​:Q→i∈I∏​Xi​ where the following diagram commutes: \usepackage {tikz-cd} \usepackage {amssymb} \begin {tikzcd} Q \\ \\ { \prod _{i \in I} X_i} && {X_i} \arrow ["{p_i}", from=3-1, to=3-3] \arrow ["{f_i}", from=1-1, to=3-3] \arrow ["{(f_i)_{i \in I}}"', from=1-1, to=3-1] \end {tikzcd}
With this definition, it is natural to ask what can serve as a nullary product. The concept is characterized by terminal objects.

A terminal object in a category \mathcal {C}C\mathcal {C}C is an object \top⊤\top⊤ of \mathcal {C}C\mathcal {C}C satisfying the following universal property: for any object XXXX in \mathcal {C}C\mathcal {C}C, there exists a unique morphism !:X \to \top!:X→⊤!:X \to \top!:X→⊤.

When making math statements, we often encounter concepts that are dual to each other. In category theory, this phenomenon is captured by the concept of duality. Intuitively, duality offers us free dual theorem from the original one.
For a category \mathcal {C}C\mathcal {C}C, the opposite category \mathcal {C}^{op}Cop\mathcal {C}^{op}Cop has the same objects as \mathcal {C}C\mathcal {C}C, but the morphisms are reversed.
For example, the product in the opposite category, all universal properties corresponds to a dual concept.

For \mathcal {C}C\mathcal {C}C a category and X, Y \in \text {Ob} { \mathcal {C}}X,Y∈ObCX, Y \in \text {Ob} { \mathcal {C}}X,Y∈ObC, the coproduct is an object X \sqcup YX⊔YX \sqcup YX⊔Y equipped with two morphisms i_X:X \to X \sqcup YiX:X→X⊔Yi_X:X \to X \sqcup YiX​:X→X⊔Y and i_Y:Y \to X \sqcup YiY:Y→X⊔Yi_Y:Y \to X \sqcup YiY​:Y→X⊔Y such that it is universal with this property. That is, for any object ZZZZ and morphisms f:X \to Zf:X→Zf:X \to Zf:X→Z and g:Y \to Zg:Y→Zg:Y \to Zg:Y→Z, there exists a unique morphism \langle f, g \rangle :X \sqcup Y \to Z⟨f,g⟩:X⊔Y→Z\langle f, g \rangle :X \sqcup Y \to Z⟨f,g⟩:X⊔Y→Z such that the following diagram commutes: \usepackage {tikz-cd} \usepackage {amssymb} \begin {tikzcd} X && {X \sqcup Y} && Y \\ \\ && Z \arrow ["{[f,g]}"', dashed, from=1-3, to=3-3] \arrow ["f"', from=1-1, to=3-3] \arrow ["{i_Y}"', from=1-5, to=1-3] \arrow ["{i_X}", from=1-1, to=1-3] \arrow ["g", from=1-5, to=3-3] \end {tikzcd}

One important principle in type theory is the Curry-Howard Isomorphism (Propositions as types). It depicts the connection between logic and types. A program can represent a logical argument, and operations in logic find meaningful correspondences in program execution. The principle was later extended with category theory due to Lambek. In his work, he showed a correspondence between STLC and Cartesian Closed Categories (CCC) and revealed the connection between types and categories. The correspondence is called the Curry-Howard-Lambek Isomorphism.

In general, there are two approaches to understand or design a type system: the syntactic view and semantic view.
The syntactic view focuses on the syntactic structure of types and programs. We study about subject reduction, cut elimination and etc, simply by manipulating the syntax. It is usually more direct and easier to understand as it is often conducted via induction on some syntactic structures. And it also suggest algorithms which can be implemented. The disadvantage is that it is limited and hard to proof some properties like normalization.
The semantic appoaches are more powerful in general. It is based on mathematics models of type systems. In exchange of the strength and generality, it is usually harder to understand and heavyweight, requries more intuition of the concepts.

One clasical semantic approach to logic is algebraic logic. A logical system is modeled by some algebraic theory. (often related to lattices and semi-lattices). Famous examples include Boolean algebras for classic propositional logic and Heyting algebras for intuitionistic counterpart. The algebraic logic is a powerful tool to study the properties of logical systems, but has a limitation that all operations are limited in one structured set.
An important result from ategorical semantics could be monads. In Moggi's paper, he showed that monads can be used to model computational effects.

It requires an operation over functors named whiskering

Categorical logic is a new approach to logic, due to Lawvere. He showed that logical constructs are fundamentally just adjoint functors. This allows us to capture many logical constructs by using only one categorical concept. Adjoint also provides a strong guarantee about the derived syntactic formulation.

Let \mathcal {C}C\mathcal {C}C and \mathcal {D}D\mathcal {D}D be categories and a pair of functors F: \mathcal {C} \to \mathcal {D}F:C→DF: \mathcal {C} \to \mathcal {D}F:C→D and G: \mathcal {D} \to \mathcal {C}G:D→CG: \mathcal {D} \to \mathcal {C}G:D→C.
